name: Amortization
definition: the process of reduction of debt or other costs through periodic charges to assets or liabilities, such as through principal payments on mortgages
label: amortization

name: Debt
definition: obligation to pay something, such as an amount of money, good, service, or instrument
explanatoryNote: In cases where the debtor and payer are the same legal person, then a debt is equivalent to a payment obligation.
label: debt

name: ExplicitContractEventSchedule
definition: schedule of events, including but not limited to payment events, rate reset events and others that will occur over the lifetime of the credit agreement
label: explicit contract event schedule
explanatoryNote: This is a schedule of actual dates and events that are terms of the contract.

name: Interest
definition: the cost of using credit, or another's money, expressed as a rate per period of time, payable by a debtor to a creditor in consideration of the credit extended to the debtor
label: interest

name: InterestCalculation
label: interest calculation
definition: event reflecting the calculation of interest

name: BorrowingCapacity
explanatoryNote: The notion of borrowing capacity is related to management decisions pertaining to credit, i.e., the creditworthiness of the borrower, loan amount, risk tolerance, and so forth, and may be reassessed from time to time depending on the type of credit agreement and regulatory requirements. Determining borrowing capacity is typically done as a part of loan origination, especially for residential mortgages.
definition: upper bound on the total amount of money that a lender believes a party has the ability to repay an obligation when due, as of some point in time
label: borrowing capacity

name: CreditAgreement
label: credit agreement
definition: contractual agreement in which a debtor receives something of value and typically agrees to repay the creditor by some date in the future, in some form (e.g., cash, securities, etc.), generally with interest

name: CreditFacility
definition: credit agreement that allows the borrower to periodically take out money over an extended period of time rather than reapplying for a loan every time they need funds
explanatoryNote: Credit facilities include revolving loans/lines of credit, committed facilities, letters of credit, and most retail credit accounts. They may define sub-facilities to which the lender is prepared to commit for specific purposes.
label: credit facility

name: CreditAgreementRepaidPeriodically
label: credit agreement repaid periodically
definition: credit agreement in which the principal and accrued interest may be periodically repaid or exchanged

name: InterestPaymentTerms
definition: contract terms for payment of interest on a debt
explanatoryNote: Note that in most cases, the dates and payment frequencies for interest will coincide with the dates and payment frequencies related to the principal.
label: interest payment terms

name: DebtTerms
definition: contract terms that specify the formal rights and obligations of borrower and lender under a contract in which funds are lent from the one party to the other
label: debt terms
explanatoryNote: These may be terms in a loan contract (including for example a mortgage contract) or they may be the contractual terms of a debt security.

name: AccruedInterest
label: accrued interest
definition: amount of interest that has been incurred, as of a specific date, on a loan or other financial obligation but has not yet been paid out
explanatoryNote: Accrued interest refers to the interest that has accumulated on a bond or other financial obligation since the last interest payment up to, but not including, the settlement date. This interest is earned over time but not yet paid out to the bondholder, for example. If this is a dirty price, this is the amount of accrued interest that is included in the price. This is therefore passed on to the purchaser of the bond or debt instrument.

name: InterestCalculationSchedule
explanatoryNote: The dates may be fixed, or relative to the corresponding interest payment date. It may be the same as the payment date, in arrears, or forward looking to the next interest payment.
definition: regular, contract-specific schedule including the dates on which interest is calculated
label: interest calculation schedule

name: ProjectedContractEventSchedule
explanatoryNote: A projected schedule is a regular schedule that documents the anchor dates and frequency of occurrences, using rules, rather than providing an explicit list of dates. This method will project future event dates (transaction event dates), based on the frequencies specified and may be adjusted due to calendar restrictions and other rules to deal with holidays, weekends, and so forth in addition to contract-specific events.
label: projected contract event schedule
definition: schedule of events, including but not limited to anticipated payment events, rate reset events and others that are expected to occur over the lifetime of the contract

name: Creditor
definition: a party to whom an obligation, such as an amount of money, or good, or performance of some service exists
label: creditor

name: NegativeAmortization
label: negative amortization
definition: amortization in which the payments made do not cover the interest due

name: SubFacility
label: sub-facility
explanatoryNote: Each sub-facility may have separate terms, and may be or include individual promissory notes, depending on the facility. The amount of associated with the individual sub-facilities sums to the total credit facility amount. Sub-facilities may, individually, have a stated purpose, such as to cover inventory, equipment, accounts receivable, working capital, letters of credit, and so forth.
definition: portion of a credit facility extended to the borrower for some purpose, possibly per some schedule specified in the facility

name: Borrower
label: borrower
definition: party to a credit agreement that is obligated to repay the amount borrowed (principal) with interest and other fees according to the terms of the instrument

name: Debtor
label: debtor
definition: a party that owes a debt or other obligation to another party

name: Lease
explanatoryNote: The lessor is the legal owner of the asset, while the lessee obtains the right to use the asset in return for rental payments. The lessee also agrees to abide by various conditions regarding their use of the property or equipment. For example, a person leasing a car may agree to the condition that the car will only be used for personal use.
label: lease
definition: credit agreement permitting the use of real estate, equipment or another asset, such as a vehicle, by the owner of that asset (the lessor) to a user (the lessee) for a specific period of time in return for payment as specified in the agreement

name: PhysicalCollateral
definition: asset pledged as collateral that has a material form, i.e., is a physical asset of the obligor
label: physical collateral

name: Collateral
label: collateral
definition: something pledged as security to ensure fulfillment of an obligation to another party, to lend money, extend credit, or provision securities

name: RetailCreditFacility
definition: credit facility that is a loan or line of credit used by retailers and real estate companies
label: retail credit facility

name: CommittedCreditFacility
definition: credit facility that is a confirmed source of financing for the borrower, as long as the borrower meets the conditions of the agreement
label: committed credit facility

name: ManagedInterestRate
definition: variable interest rate charged by a financial institution for borrowing that is not prescribed as a margin over base rate but is set from time to time by the institution
label: managed interest rate

name: VariableInterestRate
definition: an interest rate that is allowed to vary over the maturity of a loan or other debt instrument
label: variable interest rate

name: PrincipalPayment
label: principal payment
definition: event reflecting the actual payment of some amount of the principal of a debt

name: Lender
definition: a party that extends credit or money to a borrower with the expectation of being repaid, usually with interest
label: lender

name: CapitalLease
explanatoryNote: In the United States, such leases must be reported per Statement 13 of the Financial Accounting Standards Board. Generally, this applies to leases where the lessee acquires essentially all of the economic benefits and risks of the leased property.
label: capital lease
definition: lease that must be reflected on an organization's balance sheet as an asset and as a corresponding liability

name: Principal
definition: with respect to a debt: the value of an obligation, such as a bond or loan, raised and that must be repaid at maturity; for investments: the original amount of money invested, separate from any associated interest, dividends or capital gains
label: principal

name: CommittedSubFacility
label: committed sub-facility
definition: contractually committed portion of a credit facility that is available to the borrower and may be associated with some specific collateral

name: DayCountConvention
label: day-count convention
explanatoryNote: Day-count conventions apply to swaps, mortgages and forward rate agreements as well as bonds, each of which has its own day-count convention, which varies depending on the type of instrument, whether the interest rate is fixed or floating, and the country of issuance. Among the most common conventions are 30/360 or 365, actual/360 or 365, and actual/actual. A 30/360 convention assumes 30 days in a month and 360 days in a year. An actual/360 convention assumes the actual number of days in the given month and 360 days in the year. An actual/ actual convention uses the actual number of days in the given interest period and year.
definition: a business recurrence interval convention that is used to calculate the number of days in an interest payment, which applies to the amount of accrued interest or the present value for debt instruments

name: AmortizationSchedule
explanatoryNote: Payments are divided into equal amounts for the duration of the loan or debt instrument, making it the simplest repayment model. A greater amount of the payment is applied to interest at the beginning of the amortization schedule, while more money is applied to principal at the end.
label: amortization schedule
definition: schedule of periodic payments (repayment installments) that specify changes in the balance of the debt over time

name: PartialAmortization
label: partial amortization
definition: amortization in which the very last payment the last payment due may be a large balloon payment of all remaining principal and interest

name: PrincipalPaymentSchedule
explanatoryNote: The dates may be fixed, or expressed as an offset of the calculation dates. Typically the payment dates are fixed and calculation dates are expressed as an offset, however.
definition: regular, contract-specific schedule including the dates on which some percentage or all of the principal is due to be (re)paid
label: principal payment schedule

name: PrincipalRepaymentTerms
definition: contract terms that specify requirements for repayment of the principal
label: principal repayment terms

name: MotorVehicleLease
definition: lease of a motor vehicle for a fixed period of time at an agreed amount of money
label: motor vehicle lease
explanatoryNote: Motor vehicle leasing is commonly offered by dealers as an alternative to a vehicle purchase but is widely used by businesses as a method of acquiring (or having the use of) vehicles for business use, without the usually needed cash outlay. The key difference in a lease is that after the primary term (usually 2, 3 or 4 years) the vehicle has to either be returned to the leasing company or purchased for the residual value.

name: CollateralValueAsOfDate
definition: appraised value of the collateral for an obligation as of a given date
label: collateral value as of date

name: SecurityAgreement
label: security agreement
definition: collateral agreement that grants a financial interest in some collateral to a party that is not an owner of that collateral, specifying terms including relative duties and rights, over and above those specified in the primary contract, uregarding the disposition of the asset used as collateral

name: NonPhysicalCollateral
label: non-physical collateral
definition: asset pledged as collateral that is a financial asset, rather than physical asset

name: RevolvingLineOfCredit
definition: credit facility that enables the borrower to withdraw funds, repay, and withdraw again
explanatoryNote: Revolving credit facilities are essentially lines of credit with variable interest rates.
label: revolving line of credit

name: InterestRateResetSchedule
label: interest rate reset schedule
definition: regular, contract-specific schedule including the dates on which a rate reset, and corresponding actual rate, is recalculated

name: InterestRateReset
definition: event reflecting a potential adjustment to an interest rate, typically corresponding to a change in the underlying benchmark interest rate or index specified in the contract
label: interest rate reset
explanatoryNote: Note that depending on the contract, a rate reset can occur daily or on some other timetable, and depending on the underlying benchmark, the actual rate may or may not change. Rate resets may be associated with variable interest rate loans, scheduled reset dates for loans and other debt instruments, for example, interest rate swaps, certain kinds of bonds, and the like. The date on which interest is (re)calculated may be an explicit or date relative.

name: UncommittedCreditFacility
label: uncommitted credit facility
definition: credit facility that has yet to be confirmed as a source of financing for the borrower

name: UncommittedSubFacility
definition: sub-facility that has yet to be confirmed as a source of financing for the borrower
label: uncommitted sub-facility

name: BorrowerIdentifier
label: borrower identifier
explanatoryNote: A given identifier identifies a particular borrower with respect to at least some number of notes/facilities inside a particular institution according to some policy for minting identifiers. Optimally, there would be a single identifier for a given borrower, but due to operational issues, this is often not the case. A CIF number, or Customer Information File number, is used to link accounts across an institution to all notes/facilities owed by a given borrower.
definition: sequence of characters, capable of uniquely identifying a borrower

name: FixedInterestRate
label: fixed interest rate
definition: interest rate that does not fluctuate over the lifetime of a loan or other debt instrument

name: RateResetTimeOfDay
label: rate reset time of day
definition: time of day that an interest rate is reset, as indicated by some interest rate authority or market data provider

name: BorrowerIdentificationScheme
definition: system for allocating identifiers to borrowers
label: borrower identification scheme
explanatoryNote: Many banks and other financial institutions have internal systems for assigning identifiers to borrowers. In the United States, larger banks may use a Customer Information File (CIF) number, assigned as a part of their federally mandated Customer Information Program (CIP).

name: InterestPaymentSchedule
explanatoryNote: The dates may be fixed, or expressed as an offset of the calculation dates. Typically the payment dates are fixed and calculation dates are expressed as an offset, however.
label: interest payment schedule
definition: regular, contract-specific schedule including the dates on which interest is due to be paid

name: CreditAgreementRepaidAtMaturity
definition: credit agreement in which accrued interest may be periodically repaid or paid at maturity, but principal is paid at maturity
label: credit agreement repaid at maturity

name: Accrual
definition: the process of accumulating interest or other income that has been earned but not paid
explanatoryNote: There are legal contractual terms for the accrual of interest, as distinct from the payment of interest.
label: accrual

name: FloatingInterestRate
definition: variable interest rate that is based on a specific index or benchmark rate
explanatoryNote: The index used to determine the specific interest rate is generally included in the terms of the loan. In most cases, lenders will also charge a spread, or added percentage points on top of the established index rate. If a loan is billed as prime plus 2.5 percent, for a prime rate of 3.5 percent, the terms of the loan will require the borrower to pay off a 6 percent interest. Floating interest rates typically involve periodic reset dates for the loan, particularly when the index rate changes. Resets may also occur online at market predetermined intervals, with yearly adjustments being a common arrangement.
label: floating interest rate

name: FullAmortization
label: full amortization
definition: amortization in which the very last payment (which, if the schedule was calculated correctly, should be equal to all others) pays off all remaining principal and interest on the loan

name: InterestPayment
label: interest payment
definition: event reflecting the actual payment of interest

name: InterestRateSettingEvent
definition: event on which an initial rate for a given contract is set, which may be relative the the occurrence of some other contract lifecycle event, such as the execution date
label: interest rate setting event

name: hasOriginalTimeToMaturity
label: has time to maturity
definition: indicates the lifespan of credit agreement or offering, from the date of issuance to the scheduled maturity date

name: hasPrincipalRepaymentDate
explanatoryNote: Depending on the terms of the instrument (debt security, such as a bond, loan, etc.), this may be the date of a single payment of the debt principal or of the completion of scheduled partial redemption payments.
definition: relates an instrument to the date by which the principal must be repaid in full
label: has principal repayment date

name: hasAccrualBasis
label: has accrual basis
definition: identifies the convention that defines how interest accrues on something, that is the number of days in a month and days in a year that are counted when performing interest accrual calculations

name: DayCountConvention-30E360ISDA
definition: day-count convention that uses 30 days in a month and 360 days in a year for calculating interest payments
explanatoryNote: See ISDA 2006 Section 4.16(h),  for more details on the calculation.
label: day-count convention 30E/360 ISDA

name: hasInitialExchangeDate
label: has initial exchange date
definition: indicates the specific date when the initial exchange of assets or funds takes place
explanatoryNote: For a credit agreement, this is the initial funding date, such as the funding of the principal amount, or a portion thereof, but for other kinds of instruments, it may be something else. In the context of contracts related to swaps, options, or other derivative instruments, the initial exchange date marks the point where the parties legally commit to the terms of the agreement and exchange the initial required amounts.

name: hasInterestRateCap
label: has interest rate cap
definition: relates something, such as an agreement, or debt instrument, to the upper bound (ceiling) rate (typically annual) of interest on variable-rate debt that is to be paid by the debtor to the creditor on the debt

name: hasInterestPaymentFrequency
label: has interest payment frequency
definition: the frequency at which interest payments must be made on the debt

name: hasAnticipatedNumberOfPayments
label: has anticipated number of payments
definition: specifies the number payments promised per the terms of the contract over the lifetime of the contract assuming all payments are made

name: hasInitialPrincipalPaymentDate
definition: the date on which the first payment against the principal is due
label: has initial principal payment date

name: hasPrincipalPaymentFrequency
definition: the frequency at which payments on the principal must be made
label: has principal payment frequency

name: owes
label: owes
definition: links a party to a debt that they owe

name: isCollateralizedBy
definition: relates an agreement to an asset pledged as security
label: is collateralized by

name: isAmortizationOf
definition: links the process of reduction of debt or other costs through periodic charges to the relevant asset or liability
label: is amortization of

name: DayCountConvention-30365
label: day-count convention 30/365
definition: day-count convention that uses 30 days in a month and 365 days in a year for calculating interest payments

name: isCollateralizationOf
label: is collateralization of
definition: relates some collateral to an agreement pledging the asset as security

name: DayCountConvention-30E360
definition: day-count convention that uses 30 days in a month and 360 days in a year for calculating interest payments
label: day-count convention 30E/360
explanatoryNote: See ICMA Rule 251.1(ii), 251.2, and ISDA 2006 Section 4.16(g),  for more details on the calculation.

name: hasInitialInterestPaymentDate
label: has initial interest payment date
definition: the date on which the first interest payment is due

name: hasDenomination
definition: the face value of currency units, coins, or securities
label: has denomination

name: DayCountConvention-ActualActualICMA
definition: day-count convention that uses the actual number of days in each month and actual number of days in that year for calculating interest payments
explanatoryNote: This method ensures that all coupon payments are always for the same amount. It also ensures that all days in a coupon period are valued equally. This is the convention used for US Treasury bonds and notes, among other securities.
label: day-count convention actual/actual ICMA

name: hasInterestRate
definition: relates something, such as an agreement, or debt instrument, to the rate (typically annual) of interest that is to be paid by the debtor to the creditor on the debt
label: has interest rate

name: hasAvailableAmount
definition: indicates an amount of money available for an individual or organization to borrow
label: has available amount

name: isOwedBy
definition: links a debt to the party that owes it
label: is owed by

name: DayCountConvention-ActualActualISDA
label: day-count convention actual/actual ISDA
definition: day-count convention that uses the actual number of days in each month and actual number of days in that year for calculating interest payments
explanatoryNote: See ISDA 2006 Section 4.16(b),  for more details on the calculation.

name: hasMaturityDate
explanatoryNote: Maturity dates typically apply to debt instruments, such as notes, drafts, bonds, and other loans, but may also apply to preferred shares and other financial instruments.
definition: indicates the date on which the principal amount of an instrument is due to be repaid to the investor and interest or coupon payments stop, and/or the date on which the instrument may be redeemed
label: has maturity date

name: hasInterestPaymentDay
label: has interest payment day
definition: the day of the month on which interest payments must be made on the debt

name: DayCountConvention-Actual360
explanatoryNote: This convention is used in money markets for short-term lending of currencies, including the US dollar and Euro, and is applied in ESCB monetary policy operations. It is the convention used with repurchase agreements.
label: day-count convention actual/360
definition: day-count convention that uses the actual number of days in each month and 360 days in a year for calculating interest payments

name: hasPrincipal
definition: indicates the face value of an obligation, such as a bond or loan, that must be repaid at maturity, i.e., the base amount raised by a mortgage or other debt instrument
label: has principal

name: DayCountConvention-30360BondBasis
label: day-count convention 30/360 bond basis
explanatoryNote: See ISDA 2006 Section 4.16(f),  for more details on the calculation.
definition: day-count convention that uses 30 days in a month and 360 days in a year for calculating interest payments

name: isInterestOn
label: is interest on
definition: links a monetary amount that is the cost of using credit to the debt that it applies to

name: hasBorrower
definition: relates a contract, such as a debt instrument or credit agreement, to one or more parties that are incurring the debt
label: has borrower

name: isBasedOn
label: is based on
definition: relates something to something else on which it rests, or that supports it in some way

name: DayCountConvention-Actual365Fixed
label: day-count convention actual/365 fixed
explanatoryNote: See ISDA 2006 Section 4.16(d),  for more details on the calculation.
definition: day-count convention that uses the actual number of days in each month and 365 days in a year for calculating interest payments

name: isPrincipalOf
definition: links the value of a debt, excluding any interest or other costs of using credit, to the debt that it applies to
label: is principal of

name: hasLender
label: has lender
definition: relates a contract, such as a debt instrument or credit agreement, to one or more parties that are financing the debt

name: hasDebtAmount
definition: indicates the monetary amount of the debt
label: has debt amount
explanatoryNote: Represents the total debt amount including principal and interest

name: DayCountConvention-30360US
explanatoryNote: This convention is used for US corporate bonds and many US agency issues. It is most commonly referred to as '30/360', but the term '30/360' may also refer to any of the other conventions of this class, depending on the context. See ISDA 2006 Section 4.16(f),  for more details on the calculation
definition: day-count convention that uses 30 days in a month and 360 days in a year for calculating interest payments
label: day-count convention 30/360 US

name: hasFinalInterestPaymentDate
definition: the date on which the last interest payment is due
label: has final interest payment date

name: hasInitialInterestAccrualDate
label: has initial interest accrual date
definition: the date from which interest begins to accrue

name: hasPrincipalPaymentDay
label: has principal payment day
definition: the day of the month on which payments on the principal must be made

name: isOwed
definition: links a creditor to a debt that is outstanding and payable to them
label: is owed

name: isOwedTo
definition: links a debt to the party to which it is payable
label: is owed to

name: hasOutstandingAmount
definition: indicates an amount of money representing the principal, interest, or other amount owed at a specific point in time
label: has outstanding amount

name: governsPaymentOf
definition: links contractual terms embedded in a contract, such as interest or repayment terms to the element those terms apply to
label: governs payment of

name: hasCompoundingFrequency
label: has compounding frequency
definition: the frequency at which interest is added to the principal of the debt over the course of the agreement
